original_title: No tax concessions that favour selected few: Sri Lanka president tells gem industry
original_body_lines: ECONOMYNEXT – President Ranil Wickremesinghe has said he is committed to advancing Sri Lanka’s gem industry within the next two years, but does not believe in granting tax exemptions to do so.

“The government’s focus on gem re-export, value addition, and augmenting foreign exchange inflows necessitates a modernized gem industry. While tax relief has been a customary request, merely granting concessions without substantial sectoral growth is inadequate,” Wickremesinghe was quoted as saying by his media division at the opening of the “Gem Sri Lanka 2024” Gem and Jewellery Exhibition today (11).

“The key lies in concurrent development and strengthening of economic foundations for everyone involved in the industry, alongside fostering knowledge enhancement for gem polishers,” Wickremesinghe said.

“I strongly oppose the proposal to grant tax exemptions merely for individuals to amass personal wealth. My objective is to foster substantial growth in the industry over the next two years, with a particular focus on benefiting the communities in Beruwala, Ratnapura and Laggala.
“This approach should not only contribute to the national welfare but also ensure widespread prosperity within the industry.”
Wickremesinghe highlighted plans for modernization within the gem and jewellery sector to transform it into a sector that contributes to the country’s foreign exchange earnings.
Wickremesinghe has been emphasizing the need for a new economic system geared towards exports.
In his budget speech he said there would be a comprehensive policy framework formulated for the gem industry.

“In the forthcoming two months, efforts are underway to craft this policy framework, signalling a stride toward the prosperity of our nation’s gem industry. Sri Lanka, with its vast potential in gems, stands poised for remarkable progress.”
“As Ian Fleming once immortalized diamonds by saying “diamonds are forever,” we proudly affirm that Sri Lanka’s gems, including the enduring sapphires, share a timeless legacy.”
The exhibition, organized by the China Fort Gems and Jewellery Trade Association and hosted at the Bentota Cinnamon Bay Hotel, will run until January 13. (Colombo/Jan11/2024)
